answers.body_markdown:
Let *A*<sub>*i*</sub> be the value of `A` after iteration *i*, where *A*<sub>0</sub> is 100.

Let's create a recursive formula for *A*<sub>*i*</sub>:

> *A*<sub>*i*</sub> = *A*<sub>*i*−1</sub> · 1.1 − *B*

If we expand it out, we get:

> *A*<sub>*i*</sub> = (*A*<sub>*i*−2</sub> · 1.1 − *B*) · 1.1 − *B* = *A*<sub>*i*−2</sub> · 1.1<sup>2</sup> − *B* · 1.1 − *B*  
> *A*<sub>*i*</sub> = (*A*<sub>*i*−3</sub> · 1.1 − *B*) · 1.1<sup>2</sup> − *B* · 1.1 − *B* = *A*<sub>*i*−3</sub> · 1.1<sup>3</sup> − *B* · 1.1<sup>2</sup> − *B* · 1.1 − *B*  
> ...  
> *A*<sub>*i*</sub> = *A*<sub>0</sub> · 1.1<sup>*i*</sup> − *B* · (1.1<sup>0</sup> + 1.1<sup>1</sup> + ⋯ + 1.1<sup>*i*−1</sup>)

So:

> *A*<sub>*i*</sub> = 100 · 1.1<sup>*i*</sup> − 10 · *B* · (1.1<sup>*i*</sup> − 1)  

Or in general:

> *A*<sub>*i*</sub> = *A*<sub>*0*</sub> · (1 + *p*)<sup>*i*</sup> − *B* · <sup>((1 + *p*)<sup>*i*</sup> - 1)</sup> / <sub>*p*</sub>

To find the iteration *i* after which `A == 0`, we can set *A*<sub>*i*</sub> = 0 and solve for *i*:

> 0 = *A*<sub>*i*</sub>  
> 0 = 100 · 1.1<sup>*i*</sup> − 10 · *B* · (1.1<sup>*i*</sup> − 1)  
> 1.1<sup>*i*</sup> = 10 · *B* · (1.1<sup>*i*</sup> − 1)  
> *i* = log<sub>1.1</sub> (<sup>10 · *B*</sup> / <sub>(10 · *B* − 100)</sub>)

Or in general:

> *i* = log<sub>p + 1</sub> (<sup>-*B*</sup> / <sub>(*p* · *A*<sub>*0*</sub> − *B*)</sub>)

For *B* = 20, this gives *i* = 7.2. We round up, and indeed get 8.

Time complexity is `O(1)`.

If I have a value A which is being incremented by 10% of its current value while being taken away by a fixed amount B, how can I calculate how many loops will be needed to reach 0 without actually looping?

So this is how I would find it by looping:
```
LoopsNeeded = 0
A = 100
B = 20
while A > 0:
   C = A * 0.1
   A = A + C
   A = A - B
   LoopsNeeded = LoopsNeeded + 1
print(LoopsNeeded)
```
**On the first loop:**
``` 
initial values
A = 100
B = 20
-------
A > 0 = True
C = A(100) * 0.1 = 10
A = A(100) + C(10) = 110
A = A(110) - B(20) = 90
LoopsNeeded = 1
-------
A is now 90 on the next round of the loop
```

This results in 8 loops needed in total, if I do this with really big numbers, this loop may take a long time, what is a shorter way of doing this?

answers.body_markdown:
>but again I don't understand why does it require toString() to work well.

[```Double.parseDouble()``` takes an argument of type ```String```](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/Double.html#parseDouble(java.lang.String)).

The ```getText()``` method evidently returns something other than a ```String``` and therefore you need to convert.

Appending an empty string is a hacky way to force a ```String``` conversion (the ```+``` operator with one ```String``` argument implicitly calls ```toString()``` on the other argument).  Prefer an explicit ```toString()``` call.

The 's:' is simply the parameter name as used by ```parseDouble()```, and is displayed by your IDE as a hint. It's not actually modifying your source code.
answers.title: What does "s:" mean here?

answers.body_markdown:
The `android.widget.TextView.getText()` method is declared as returning a `CharSequence` rather than a `String`.  (See [javadoc][1].)

The `CharSequence` interface is one of the declared interfaces of `String`.  (See [javadoc][2].)

The `Double.parseDouble` takes a `String` argument.  (See [javadoc][3].)

Therefore there is a type mismatch in this:

    val1 = Double.parseDouble(ioTxt.getText());  // expects String
                                                 // provided CharSequence

but this works:

    val1 = Double.parseDouble(ioTxt.getText().toString());

because `toString()` is converting the `CharSequence` to a `String`.   And this is another way of doing the conversion:

    val1 = Double.parseDouble(ioTxt.getText() + "");

-------------------------

Note however that this is not valid Java code:

    val1 = Double.parseDouble(s: ioTxt.getText()+"");

You are *most likely* misinterpreting what your IDE is saying.  


  [1]: https://developer.android.com/reference/android/widget/TextView.html#getText()
  [2]: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/lang/CharSequence.html
  [3]: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/lang/Double.html#parseDouble-java.lang.String-
answers.title: What does "s:" mean here?

answers.body_markdown:
[parseDouble][1] accepts String as parameter.


  [1]: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/Double.html#parseDouble(java.lang.String)

You are getting error as you are trying to pass a double instead of String. 

For second question,
compiler never adds anything to your source files. The "s:" you see, is a way of IDE you are using, to show the parameter you are setting while calling the method.

answers.body_markdown:
I am not sure, why you implemented your own stack class, based on a linked list. With new. And no delete (so creating memory leaks) and other design flawsm. Maybe you did for academic purposes. I do not know. If ther is really a reason for reinventing the wheel and not use the STL ````std::stack```` container, then please look at the STL ````std::stack```` interface and implement the same functions in your code.

Do not mix up functionalities. In your pop function (that belongs to stack functionalities) you are writing about 'brackets'. The design flaw here is that you did not implement the stack ````empty```` function. Before you call ````pop````, you should check for ````empty````.

Anyway, I would recommend to use a ````std::vector```` for all this.

There are many more problems in your code, but you will learn and find out.

Now to your question. Basically you are answering already for yourself.

What you are doing is

 - Read a line
 - Check (with bc) if in THIS and only THIS and NOT in other lines are matching brackets
 - After evaluation of this ONE line (with bc), the ````stack s;```` variable will go out of scope and vanish (leaving a lot of memeory leaks)
 - Then you read the next line of the file (forgetting everything, what you did before)

Solution:

You should define the stack in main and then pass it to your bc function as reference.



And then you need to fix the rest of the bugs . . .

answers.body_markdown:
The `group` aesthetic determines what coordinates are considered part of the same polygon. By giving each rectangle a unique group identifier, you can prevent this merge.

```
datapoly$group <- rep(1:4, each = 4)
p <- ggplot(datapoly, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_polygon(aes(fill = value, group = group)) + 
  coord_fixed(ratio = 5) + 
  scale_y_discrete(limit = c(1.5, 5.5), labels = c("1234", "14"))
```

[![enter image description here][1]][1]

EDIT: In case of more groups, this seems to be the plot you want, no?:

```
ids <- factor(c("atp6", "atp8", "cob", "cox1", "cox2"))
positions <- data.frame(
  id = rep(ids, each = 4),
  x = c(1, 1575, 1575, 1, 1541, 1601, 1601, 1541, 1602, 2288, 2288, 1602, 2290, 2350, 2350, 2290, 2351, 2515, 2515, 2351,
        1, 1557, 1557, 1, 1541, 1603, 1603, 1541, 1605, 2285, 2285, 1605, 2288, 2350, 2350, 2288, 2351, 2509, 2509, 2351),
  y = c(1, 1, 2, 2, 2.1, 2.1, 3.1, 3.1, 1, 1, 2, 2, 2.1, 2.1, 3.1, 3.1, 1, 1, 2, 2, 
        4, 4, 5, 5, 5.1, 5.1, 6.1, 6.1, 4, 4, 5, 5, 5.1, 5.1, 6.1, 6.1, 4, 4, 5, 5) 
)

ggplot(positions, aes(x, y, group = id, fill = id)) +
  geom_polygon() +

  scale_y_discrete(limit = c(1.5, 5.5, 9.5, 13.5), labels = c("013", "023", "1008", "101"))
```

It might be that the `merge` operation does something funky to the ordering of your polygons, whereby the `rep(1:10, each = 4)` does not seem to be correct for multiple groups.

answers.body_markdown:
It's telling you that you're passing an invalid Integer Literal Value (0xa0) to your function int() in the block of code `for b in range (0,int(num))`

If you're going to pass a Hexadecimal value to the int function, you need to specify the numeric base (16) as the 2nd parameter of the int function `int("0xa0",16)`

answers.body_markdown:
As a slice is determined by a starting and ending index, this is the same as asking how many distinct pairs can be picked from *n+1* elements (counting the 0<sup>th</sup> and n<sup>th</sup> index), where the order of the pair is not important.

That is counting [combinations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combination), and the formula for *"n+1 select 2"* is: *n(n+1)/2*.

NB: This does not count empty slices. If those are to be counted also, and empty slices should be counted separately if their index is different, then this is counting multi-sets of 2 (as start/end index then can be equal). Then you should add an additional *n+1* to the above result.
answers.title: How to calculate quantity of all slices of array consisting N elements?

answers.body_markdown:
Let `S(n)` is a count of all slices of array of n elements.
Then `S(n) = n*(n+1)/2`.

Proof using mathematics induction approach.
1. Base `n = 1` 

    A = [a1]

number of slices is 1. `S(1)= 1*2/2 = 1`
2. Let `S(n) = n*(n+1)/2`
3. Check `S(n+1)=(n+1)*(n+2)/2`
   Array of `n+1` elements is
   

    [a1,a2,...,aN,a(N+1)]

   It has slices of array of n elements `[a1,a2,...,aN]` plus new slices:
  

    (a(N+1)), (a(N+1), aN), (a(N+1), aN, a(N-1)), ... , (a(N+1),aN,...,a1)

Count of new slices (having inside element `a(N+1)`) is `n+1`.
Hence count of all slices equals to count of slices of array of n elements plus `n+1`.

    S(n+1) = S(n) + n+1 = n(n+1)/2 + n+1 = (n^2 + n + 2n + 2)/2=(n^2+3n+2)/2

And substituting `n+1` instead `n` into formula in step 2 we have:
`S(n+1)=(n+1)(n+1+1)/2=(n+1)(n+2)/2=(n^2+3n+2)/2`. 
It proves the formula.

Also it gives useful relation:

    S(n+1) - S(n) = n + 1

meaning difference of slices count for array of `n+1` and `n` elements is `n+1`.
Examples: 

    A1 = [a1], A2 = [a1,a2] S(1)= 1, S(2)=3 and S(2)-S(1)=2=1+1, n=1
    A3 = [a1,a2,a3], S(3)=6, S(3)-S(2)=3=2+1, n=2
    A4 = [a1,a2,a3,a4], S(4)=10, S(4)-S(3)=4=3+1, n=3
answers.title: How to calculate quantity of all slices of array consisting N elements?

items.body_markdown:
Given array of `N` elements `A = [a1, a2, ..., aN]`. Slice is any sequence of adjacent elements. Like

How to calculate count of all slices of the array?

answers.body_markdown:
It will never allow an encrypted character to exceed its supposed range, that is, a - z. The ascii of a and z are 97 and 122 respectively, and you would want the Caesar cipher encryption within this range of characters only.

This will check if the ascii code of `ch` is greater than the ascii of z

    if(ch > 'z'){

If yes, it will calculate: (ascii of `ch`) - (ascii of `z`) + (ascii of `a`) - 1.

    ch = (char)(ch - 'z' + 'a' - 1);

It is translated into `ch = (char)(ch - 122 + 97 - 1);`

Suppose you want to encrypt character `a` with a key `3`. The program will take 97 (ascii of `a`) + 3. You will get 100, which is the ascii of `d`. Yet, what if you want to encrypt `z` with a key `3`? 

Same as before, it will take 122 (ascii of `z`) + 3 = 125. However, 125 is not found in the range 97 - 122 (a-z). Thus, you will get an unwanted character (in this case, 125 is the ascii of `}`).

Therefore, `(ch - 'z' + 'a' - 1)` will ensure that any character exceeding ascii 122, will be converted back into a character with ascii range of 97 and 122 inclusive only. In the example of 125, `ch = (char)(125 - 122 + 97 - 1)` => `ch = (char)(99)` => `ch = c`.

answers.body_markdown:
The _**short**_ answer is:

 1. `eta11` is the rotation parameter, *i.e.* when you do decomposition of the residuals inside the equation for the conditional variance, you can allow a _shift_ (`eta2`) or/and _rotation_ (`eta1`) in the _news impact curve_. 
 2. `alpha1` is the `ARCH(q)` parameter. In your case, `q` is 1.
 3. `beta1` is the `GARCH(p)` parameter. In your case, `p` is 1.

_**Additional information**_:

You are looking at the following _family_ of `GARCH` equations, collectively called `fGARCH` in `rugarch` package:


----------
[![enter image description here][1]][1]

----------
For _threshold_ `GARCH` (`tGARCH`) models: 

[![enter image description here][2]][2]

and

[![enter image description here][3]][3]

while 

[![enter image description here][4]][4]
 

You have also `mu` parameter estimated since you have selected `include.mean = TRUE`. The parameter `shape` is a numeric value denoting the shape parameter of the conditional distribution of standardized residuals `z_t`. Lastly, the parameter `omega` in your model is the _variance intercept parameter_.

Hope this helps.

answers.body_markdown:
In MySQL 8.0, you can `JOIN` both tables and use `RANK()` to get the latest records in each group of records sharing the same `code`:

    SELECT roll, name, code, amount
    FROM (
    	SELECT
    		s.roll,
    		s.name,
    		s.code,
    		f.amount,
    		RANK() OVER(PARTITION BY f.code ORDER BY STR_TO_DATE(f.datenewfee, '%d-%M-%Y') DESC) rk
    	FROM fee f
    	INNER JOIN students s ON s.code = f.code
    ) x 
    WHERE rk = 1

In earlier versions, you can use a crrelated subquery with a `NOT EXISTS` condition to filter on the recent records per group:

	SELECT
		s.roll,
		s.name,
		s.code,
		f.amount
	FROM fee f
	INNER JOIN students s ON s.code = f.code
	WHERE NOT EXISTS (
		SELECT 1
		FROM fee f1
		WHERE f1.code = f.code 
		AND STR_TO_DATE(f1.datenewfee, '%d-%M-%Y') > STR_TO_DATE(f.datenewfee, '%d-%M-%Y')
	)

**[Demo on DB Fiddle](https://www.db-fiddle.com/f/sn5khcvkDVdQtPKi8jGazf/0)**:

Both queries return:

    | roll | name  | code | amount |
    | ---- | ----- | ---- | ------ |
    | 1120 | aaaaa | 111  | 700    |
    | 1121 | eeeee | 111  | 700    |
    | 1122 | hhhh  | 112  | 800    |
    | 1123 | bbbb  | 111  | 700    |
    | 1124 | jjjj  | 112  | 800    |

answers.body_markdown:
Got the problem solved.

Issue is with the color format.

ImageDataGenerator outputs in RGB format whereas opencv imread reads it in BGR format.

So a BGR2RGB conversion is used to solve the issue.
```
image = cv2.cvtColor(image,cv2.COLOR_BGR2RGB)
```

Also the default image resizer in ImageDataGenerator is "Nearest", i have used the same in opencv resize as well.

answers.body_markdown:
You are counting along multiple dimensions.  There are multiple approaches to fixing this.  The simplest modification is to replace the `count()` with `count(distinct)`:

    SELECT emp.[ecode],
           COUNT(DISTINCT sch.<primary key>) as schedulecount,
           COUNT(DISTINCT ord.<primary key>) as noordercount,
           COUNT(DISTINCT sto.<primary key>) as salescount
    FROM . . .

The column being counted is the primary key from each of the tables.

However, this is not optimal (generally) from a performance perspective.  You also lose `ecode`s that are missing *any* of the values (because you are using inner joins).

I think I would recommend correlated subqueries for this:

    SELECT e.ecode,
           (SELECT COUNT(*)
            FROM mydb..schedule s 
            WHERE s.user_id = e.ecode
           ) as schedulecount,
           (SELECT COUNT(*)
            FROM mydb..order o 
            WHERE o.user_id = e.ecode
           ) as noordercount,
           (SELECT COUNT(*)
            FROM mydb..store s 
            WHERE s.user_id = e.ecode
           ) as salescount
    FROM [mydb].[dbo].[employee] e
    ORDER BY e.[ecode] DESC;
answers.title: How to count records after joining multiple tables in SQL

answers.body_markdown:
An alternative approach is to use `APPLY` in the `FROM` to get the counts:

    USE mydb;
    
    
    SELECT emp.ecode,
           Sc.schedulecount,
           O.noordercount,
           St.salescount
    FROM dbo.employee emp
         CROSS APPLY (SELECT COUNT(*) AS schedulecount
                      FROM dbo.schedule sch
                      WHERE sch.user_id = emp.ecode) Sc
         CROSS APPLY (SELECT COUNT(*) AS noordercount
                      FROM dbo.[order] ord --Generally it's a good idea to avoid Reserved Keywords for Object names
                      WHERE ord.ecode = emp.ecode) O
         CROSS APPLY (SELECT COUNT(*) AS salescount
                      FROM dbo.store sto
                      WHERE sto.ecode = emp.ecode) St
    ORDER BY emp.ecode DESC;

[db<>fiddle](https://dbfiddle.uk/?rdbms=sqlserver_2017&fiddle=1f48481ef042423ab0bd554c7f6bf9b3) showing results are correct per question.

*Crystal ball*:

    SELECT emp.ecode,
           Sc.schedulecount,
           O.noordercount,
           St.salescount
    FROM dbo.employee emp
         CROSS APPLY (SELECT COUNT(*) AS schedulecount
                      FROM dbo.schedule sch
                      WHERE sch.user_id = emp.ecode) Sc
         CROSS APPLY (SELECT COUNT(*) AS noordercount
                      FROM dbo.[order] ord --Generally it's a good idea to avoid Reserved Keywords for Object names
                      WHERE ord.ecode = emp.ecode) O
         CROSS APPLY (SELECT COUNT(*) AS salescount
                      FROM dbo.store sto
                      WHERE sto.ecode = emp.ecode) St
    WHERE Sc.schedulecount > 0	
       OR O.noordercount > 0
       OR St.salescount > 0
    ORDER BY emp.ecode DESC;

answers.body_markdown:
Spark offers plenty of APIs/Functions to play around, most of the time default functions come handy however for a specific task UserDefinedFunctions UDFs could be written.

Reference https://jaceklaskowski.gitbooks.io/mastering-spark-sql/spark-sql-udfs.html

    import org.apache.spark.sql.expressions.UserDefinedFunction
    import org.apache.spark.sql.functions.udf
    import org.apache.spark.sql.functions.col
    import spark.implicits._
    
    val df = spark.sparkContext.parallelize(Seq(1,3)).toDF("index")
    val rangeDF = df.withColumn("range", indexToRange(col("index")))
    rangeDF.show(10)
    
    def indexToRange: UserDefinedFunction = udf((index: Integer) => for (i <- 0 to index) yield i)

        val input_df = spark.sparkContext.parallelize(List(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)).toDF("col1")

        val output_df = input_df.rdd.map(x => x(0).toString()).map(x => (x, Range(0, x.toInt + 1).mkString(","))).toDF("col1", "col2")
        output_df.withColumn("col2", split($"col2", ",")).show(false)

You can use "com.google.cloud.datastore" which is a wrapper that uses v1 library [link](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/41471190/difference-between-com-google-datastore-v1-and-com-google-cloud-datastore-miss).

answers.title: Is Google.Cloud.Datastore.V1.DatastoreDb thread-safe?

answers.body_markdown:
Yes, `DatastoreDb` doesn't contain any local mutable state, and is thread-safe. We recommend that you use a single instance of it to avoid potentially opening more network connections than are necessary.

`DatastoreTransaction`, however, *does* contain local state, and is *not* thread-safe. (It has no thread affinity, but there's no protection against multiple threads attempting to add mutations at the same time, for example.)

answers.body_markdown:
> FAILED! => {"changed": false, "msg": "Unsupported parameters for (replace) module: when"}

In the future, post the **real** playbook or task that you are running, without editoralizing, since it would otherwise be impossible for people to help you without seeing what you are really running

As is clearly stated in the error message, the `replace:` task does not accept a `when:` parameter. You are in that situation because you have mis-indented your `when:` statement

    # you have, which is _incorrect_
    - replace:
        dest: "/path/to/my/apps/{{ name_of_app }}/config/{{ name_of_app }}.config"
        when: 1 == 1

but it should be:

    - replace:
        dest: "/path/to/my/apps/{{ name_of_app }}/config/{{ name_of_app }}.config"
      when: 1 == 1

answers.body_markdown:
You are missing `:` at the end of `if` statements. 

Change:

    if finalfact % n == 0

To:

    if finalfact % n == 0: 

And:

    if (finalfact/n) % n == 0

To:

     if (finalfact/n) % n == 0: 

---

Need to indent the code properly: 

Change:

    for i in range(1,n):
    fact = fact * i

To:

    for i in range(1,n):
        fact = fact * i

---

Also: 

    finalfact / n     # 5 / 2 = 2.5

Should be: 

    finalfact // n    # 5 // 2 = 2

answers.body_markdown:
Rather than summing the count of each cashtag, you should sum its presence or absence, since you don't care how many times each cashtag occurs, only how many cashtags.

```
for tag in cashtags:
    count += tag in tweet
```

Or more succinctly: `sum(tag in tweet for tag in cashtags)`

To make the comparison case insensitive, you can upper case the tweets beforehand. Additionally, it would be more idiomatic to filter on a temporary series and avoid explicitly looping over the dataframe (though you may need to read up more about Pandas to understand how this works):

```
df[df.Current.apply(lambda tweet: sum(tag in tweet.upper() for tag in cashtags)) == 1]
```
answers.title: Removing rows from a DataFrame based on words in a string

answers.body_markdown:
If you ever want to generalise your question to any tag, then this is a good place for a regular expression. 
You want to match against `(\$w+)(?!.*/1)` see e.g. [here][1] for a detailed explanation, but the general structure is:

- `\$w+`: find a dollar sign followed by one or more letters/numbers (or
   an `_`), if you just wanted to count how many tags you had this is all you need

e.g. 

```
df.Current.str.count(r'\$\w+')
```
will print
```
0    3
1    2
2    1
3    2
4    1
5    2
```

but this will remove cases where you have the same element more than once so you need to add a negative lookahead meaning don't match 

- `(?!.*/1)`: Is a negative lookahead, this means **don't** match if it is followed by the same match later on. This will mean that only the last tag is counted in the string.

Using this, you can then use pandas `DataFrame.str` methods, specifically `DataFrame.str.count` (the `re.I` does a case insensitive match)
 
```
import re
df[df.Current.str.count(r'(\$\w+)(?!.*\1)', re.I) == 1]
```
which will give you your desired output
```
                                             Current
2                   $AAPL earnings announcement soon
3  $FB is releasing a new product. Will $FB's pro...
4                               $Fb doing good today
5   $AMZN high today. Will $amzn continue like this?
```

[1]: https://docs.python.org/3/library/re.html#regular-expression-syntax

answers.title: How to disable all other things exept the current frame?

answers.body_markdown:
One option could be to first disable all except that frame and then enable explicitly the frame.

Given that `FRAME-A` is what you want enabled:

    DISABLE ALL WITH FRAME DEFAULT-FRAME.
    ENABLE ALL WITH FRAME FRAME-A.

The code below gives a couple of examples of enable/disable (and some bogus interface details). It is however quite long since it's graphical "appbuilder" code including loads of preprocessors.

Paste it into a procedure editor and run! 

    &Scoped-define WINDOW-NAME C-Win
    /*------------------------------------------------------------------------
    
      File: 
    
      Description: 
    
      Input Parameters:
          <none>
    
      Output Parameters:
          <none>
    
      Author: 
    
      Created: 
    
    ------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
    /*          This .W file was created with the Progress AppBuilder.      */
    /*----------------------------------------------------------------------*/
    
    /* Create an unnamed pool to store all the widgets created 
         by this procedure. This is a good default which assures
         that this procedure's triggers and internal procedures 
         will execute in this procedure's storage, and that proper
         cleanup will occur on deletion of the procedure. */
    
    CREATE WIDGET-POOL.
    
    /* ***************************  Definitions  ************************** */
    
    /* Parameters Definitions ---                                           */
    
    /* Local Variable Definitions ---                                       */
    
    
    
    /* ********************  Preprocessor Definitions  ******************** */
    
    &Scoped-define PROCEDURE-TYPE Window
    &Scoped-define DB-AWARE no
    
    /* Name of designated FRAME-NAME and/or first browse and/or first query */
    &Scoped-define FRAME-NAME DEFAULT-FRAME
    
    /* Standard List Definitions                                            */
    &Scoped-Define ENABLED-OBJECTS BUTTON-3 RADIO-SET-1 BUTTON-4 
    &Scoped-Define DISPLAYED-OBJECTS RADIO-SET-1 
    
    /* Custom List Definitions                                              */
    /* List-1,List-2,List-3,List-4,List-5,List-6                            */
    
    /* ***********************  Control Definitions  ********************** */
    
    /* Define the widget handle for the window                              */
    DEFINE VAR C-Win AS WIDGET-HANDLE NO-UNDO.
    
    /* Definitions of the field level widgets                               */
    DEFINE BUTTON BUTTON-3 
         LABEL "Disable all" 
         SIZE 15 BY 1.14.
    
    DEFINE BUTTON BUTTON-4 
         LABEL "Enable all" 
         SIZE 15 BY 1.14.
    
    DEFINE VARIABLE RADIO-SET-1 AS INTEGER 
         VIEW-AS RADIO-SET VERTICAL

              "Item 1", 1,
    "Item 2", 2,

    DEFINE BUTTON BUTTON-2

         SIZE 19 BY 1.14.
    
    DEFINE BUTTON BUTTON-5 
         LABEL "Enable this frame" 
         SIZE 19 BY 1.14.
    
    DEFINE VARIABLE COMBO-BOX-1 AS CHARACTER FORMAT "X(256)":U

    /* ************************  Control Triggers  ************************ */
    
    &Scoped-define SELF-NAME C-Win

      /* This case occurs when the user presses the "Esc" key.
         In a persistently run window, just ignore this.  If we did not, the
         application would exit. */
      IF THIS-PROCEDURE:PERSISTENT THEN RETURN NO-APPLY.
    END.
    
    
    ON WINDOW-CLOSE OF C-Win /* <insert window title> */
    DO:
      /* This event will close the window and terminate the procedure.  */

    END.

    ON CHOOSE OF BUTTON-4 IN FRAME DEFAULT-FRAME /* Enable all */
    DO:
        ENABLE ALL WITH FRAME DEFAULT-FRAME.
    END.
    
    
    &Scoped-define FRAME-NAME FRAME-B
    &Scoped-define SELF-NAME BUTTON-5
    ON CHOOSE OF BUTTON-5 IN FRAME FRAME-B /* Enable this frame */
    DO:
        ENABLE ALL WITH FRAME {&FRAME-NAME}.
    END.
    
    
    &Scoped-define FRAME-NAME FRAME-A
    &Scoped-define SELF-NAME BUTTON-6
    ON CHOOSE OF BUTTON-6 IN FRAME FRAME-A /* Enable all but this frame */
    DO:
        ENABLE ALL WITH FRAME DEFAULT-FRAME.
    END.
    
    
    &Scoped-define FRAME-NAME DEFAULT-FRAME
    &UNDEFINE SELF-NAME
    
    
    
    /* ***************************  Main Block  *************************** */
    
    /* Set CURRENT-WINDOW: this will parent dialog-boxes and frames.        */
    ASSIGN CURRENT-WINDOW                = {&WINDOW-NAME} 
           THIS-PROCEDURE:CURRENT-WINDOW = {&WINDOW-NAME}.
    
    /* The CLOSE event can be used from inside or outside the procedure to  */
    /* terminate it.                                                        */
    ON CLOSE OF THIS-PROCEDURE 
       RUN disable_UI.
    
    /* Best default for GUI applications is...                              */
    PAUSE 0 BEFORE-HIDE.
    
    /* Now enable the interface and wait for the exit condition.            */
    /* (NOTE: handle ERROR and END-KEY so cleanup code will always fire.    */
    MAIN-BLOCK:
    DO ON ERROR   UNDO MAIN-BLOCK, LEAVE MAIN-BLOCK
       ON END-KEY UNDO MAIN-BLOCK, LEAVE MAIN-BLOCK:
      RUN enable_UI.
      IF NOT THIS-PROCEDURE:PERSISTENT THEN
        WAIT-FOR CLOSE OF THIS-PROCEDURE.
    END.
    
    
    /* **********************  Internal Procedures  *********************** */
    
    PROCEDURE disable_UI :
    /*------------------------------------------------------------------------------
      Purpose:     DISABLE the User Interface
      Parameters:  <none>
      Notes:       Here we clean-up the user-interface by deleting
                   dynamic widgets we have created and/or hide 
                   frames.  This procedure is usually called when
                   we are ready to "clean-up" after running.
    ------------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
      /* Delete the WINDOW we created */
      IF SESSION:DISPLAY-TYPE = "GUI":U AND VALID-HANDLE(C-Win)
      THEN DELETE WIDGET C-Win.
      IF THIS-PROCEDURE:PERSISTENT THEN DELETE PROCEDURE THIS-PROCEDURE.
    END PROCEDURE.
    
    PROCEDURE enable_UI :
    /*------------------------------------------------------------------------------
      Purpose:     ENABLE the User Interface
      Parameters:  <none>
      Notes:       Here we display/view/enable the widgets in the
                   user-interface.  In addition, OPEN all queries
                   associated with each FRAME and BROWSE.
                   These statements here are based on the "Other 
                   Settings" section of the widget Property Sheets.
    ------------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
      DISPLAY RADIO-SET-1 
          WITH FRAME DEFAULT-FRAME IN WINDOW C-Win.

          WITH FRAME DEFAULT-FRAME IN WINDOW C-Win.

          WITH FRAME FRAME-B IN WINDOW C-Win.
      {&OPEN-BROWSERS-IN-QUERY-FRAME-B}

answers.body_markdown:
When you create a function, pass in all the information the function needs as arguments. Don't read data from external sources like other cells. If the function needs it, pass it in.

Don't name arguments the same as your function name. To return a value, assign that value to the name of the function. If you have an argument with the same name, it gets confused.

This example doesn't add up because I didn't understand all the conditions, but it should give you a start and you can fix what's wrong.

    Public Function Score(ByVal Runs As Long, ByVal Balls As Long, ByVal Fours As Long, ByVal Sixers As Long, _
        ByVal RunFactor As Long, ByVal FourFactor As Long, ByVal SixerFactor As Long, _
        ByVal HalfFactor As Long, ByVal CentFactor As Long, _
        ByVal Rate1Factor As Long, ByVal Rate2Factor As Long, ByVal Rate3Factor As Long) As Double
        
        Dim dReturn As Double
        
        dReturn = (Runs * RunFactor) + (Fours * FourFactor) + (Sixers * SixerFactor)
        
        If Runs >= 50 Then dReturn = dReturn + HalfFactor
        If Runs >= 100 Then dReturn = dReturn + (CentFactor - HalfFactor)
        
        Select Case Runs / Balls
            Case Is < 0.5
                dReturn = dReturn - Rate1Factor
            Case Is <= 59.9
                dReturn = dReturn - Rate2Factor
            Case Is <= 70
                dReturn = dReturn - Rate3Factor
        End Select
        
        Score = dReturn
        
    End Function

You don't need a separate variable (dReturn) but I like to use one. You use the function in a cell like this

    =score(F2,G2,H2,I2,1,1,2,8,16,3,2,1)

Note that my factors are all hardcoded, but you could point those to ranges too

    =score(F2,G2,H2,I2,Sheet2!A1,Sheet2!A2,Sheet2!A3,Sheet2!A4,Sheet2!A5,Sheet2!A6,Sheet2!A7,Sheet2!A8)

Even better, use named ranges

    =score(F2,G2,H2,I2,Run,Four,Sixer,Half,Century,Strike1,Strike2,Strike3)

I am not aware of the executor launching policy in spark. I had run the spark job using spark standalone cluster manager. My doubt is regarding the executor launching policy in spark when the spark dynamic allocation is not enabled. 
The behavior I found was that in my application at a time 10 executor remained in running state. My doubt is when I specified spark.cores.max = 20 and spark.executor.cores = 2.
Ideally 10 executors should be launched and those 10 executors should be live throughout the spark application life. Why spark exits the active executor and launches new executors it can use already launched executors.
items.title: spark executor launching or exiting policy

items.body_markdown:
I need to get a notification whenever i receive money in paypal (its sent via F&F). So i've been going through the api and found various options to fetch all *payment* data, such as [this repo for example](https://github.com/paypal/PayPal-Python-SDK/blob/master/samples/payment/all.py), which could allow me to write a small bot, checking the api for new payments every X Minutes. However, i only get my payments, instead of the payments i received.

The other option to solve that problem would be to get a Notification whenever my paypal.me link is successfully used. There is sadly not much documentation on how to get this data via the API. I've read quite a lot about IDN, but thats apparently only offered for business accounts with a offical pay-pal button and website etc. All things i dont have, i only send paypal.me links, and need to get the senders mail and the amount (amount is satisfied by E-Mail Notification, but the senders mail is crucial).

Has anyone successfully received all the activities / installed a IDN for a paypal.me link? Reffering to the "official" paypal forums, there are also people asking related questions, but dont receive any attention.
items.title: Webhook / IDN or API-Call for F&F Transactions via Paypal.me?

items.body_markdown:
I am trying to run a MATLAB code in Octave. There is a MATLAB function [`extractBetween`][1] that is not yet available in octave. Original code is 

    numbers = str2double(extractBetween(dirAndFileNames(:,2), 4, 5));

I have tried to replace it with this code.
    
    numbers = str2double(substr(dirAndFileNames(:,2), 4, 2));

It works for single strings but not for cell arrays. I have tried other functions that work with cell arrays like `strtrim`, `strtrunc`. I want to extract the numbers on the end but `strtrunc` gives opposite of what I want. It gives the first letters.

`dirAndFilenames(:,2)` looks like this:

    debug> dirAndFileNames(:,2)
    ans =
    {
      [1,1] = desktop.ini
      [2,1] = trn01
      [3,1] = trn02
      [4,1] = trn03
      [5,1] = trn04
      [6,1] = trn05
      [7,1] = trn06
      [8,1] = trn07
      [9,1] = trn08
      [10,1] = trn09
      [11,1] = trn10
    }

  [1]: https://www.mathworks.com/help/matlab/ref/extractbetween.html?searchHighlight=extractBetween&s_tid=doc_srchtitle
items.title: MATLAB’s extractBetween alternative for Octave in cell array
